description.narrative:
' Education is a basic human right. Every child regardless of gender in Vietnam has the right to grow up and receive education. In reality, children with disabilities (CWDs) face many difficulties in accessing quality education. As many CWDs are out of school, their opportunities and potentials are held back, and the likelihood of getting trapped in multigenerational poverty and disadvantagesincrease.
This project is designed to facilitate the implementation of the right to education of children andespecially of CWDs. The target groups include CWDs, their families and relevant implementing departments and agencies.
Firstly, the project designs training courses on the Laws on Children, Education, and Persons with Disabilities and some related policies to raise the awareness among stakeholders about child rights (including CWDs), notably in education. This is followed by capacity-building activities and theestablishment of a coordination mechanism engaging schools, communal clinics and the Communal People#s Committee (CPC) in promotingthe implementation of the rights of CWDs, especially in inclusive education. This mechanism will form a network of health workers at clinics, teachers in public schools, and commune social workers with the skills and techniques in early identification. Besides, the project also includes training courses for parents of CWDs on home-based rehabilitation techniques that actively contribute to the early intervention process to help children recover and adapt well whenstudying in public schools. The project is under coordination between the Association for Empowerment of Persons with Disabilities (AEPD) and the Quang Binh Lawyers Association. AEPD is the project host and mainly responsible for the implementation of project activities. The Lawyers Association coordinates the activitiesrelated to justice and laws, especially to the rights of CWDs in education.

participating-org.narrative: Association for Empowerment of Pers with Disabilities (AEPD)

The Association for Empowerment of Persons with Disabilities (AEPD) is a local NGO in Vietnam, born out of the international humanitarian organization, Survivor Corps/Landmine Survivors Network (SC/LSN). Our programs aim to improve the psycho-social andeconomic well-being of persons with disabilities, including those who have been injured and disabled by landmines or unexploded ordnances, orhave suffered limb loss from other war-related injuries.
During the past several years, AEPD has also led thework of the Landmine Working Group in Vietnam on advocacy issues, including Vietnam signing three international treaties affecting survivor#s lives: the Mine Ban Treaty (MBT), the Convention on Cluster Munitions (CCM), and the Convention on the Rights ofPersons with Disabilities (CRPD). In addition, AEPD has successfully organized and chaired an advocacy workshop on CCM with the Department of Foreign Affairs in Ho Chi Minh city and cooperated with the Provincial People's Aid Coordination Committee to organize the first ever national workshop on Victim Assistance and International Cooperation in Vietnam.
AEPD continues to expand its reach into local communities, building community resiliency in areas such as inclusive education for persons with disabilities, as well as climate change awareness and disaster response.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
